questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding renal vein thrombosis?

choices.text: Right renal vein is more commonly involved
Most common cause  in children is nephrotic syndrome
Investigation of choice is doppler ultrasound of renal vein
Most common cause  in elderly is renal cell carcinoma

questions.solution:
The most common cause of renal vein thrombosis in the elderly is renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

The most common causes of renal vein thrombosis in different age groups are as follows:

  • Children - Dehydration, followed by sepsis
  • Adults - Nephrotic syndrome (most commonly membranous glomerulonephritis)
  • Elderly - Renal cell carcinoma

The left renal vein is more commonly involved and 2/3rd of cases are bilateral. Doppler USG is used for screening but the investigation of choice is CT angiography.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child develops hematuria after 4 days of severe diarrhea. Peripheral smear shows fragmented RBCs and thrombocytopenia. Ultrasound reveals the enlargement of both kidneys. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal vein thrombosis secondary to dehydration.

Hematuria in children following diarrhea can be due to the following:

  Hemolytic uremic syndrome Renal vein thrombosis
Onset 5-10 days after diarrhea Depends on severity of dehydration
 Renal failure Present Present
Hematuria + +
Peripheral smear  fragmented RBCs + +
Platelets Decreased Decreased
USG kidney Normal Enlarged due to congestion by renal vein thrombosis (bilateral in 67% cases)

Henoch-Schonlein purpura would present 1-3 weeks after an upper respiratory infection. It causes hematuria, non-blanching rash over the buttocks, and abdominal pain.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome globally?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) globally is Escherichia coli O157:H7.             

The causes of HUS are as follows:

  • Infections: Usually occur 5-10 days after diarrheal diseases due to bacterial exotoxins.
    • E.coli O157:H7 - Shiga-like toxin (verotoxin)
    • Shigella dysenteriae type I - Shiga toxin
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Autoimmunity
  • Complement activation (in atypical HUS)

questions.text: Which of the following is false about hemolytic uremic syndrome?

choices.text: Symptoms and signs of HUS develops as diarrhea begins to improve
Only supportive managment of acute renal failure is done in typical HUS
Eculizumab improves microangiopathic hemolytic anemia in atypical HUS
Coomb's positive hemolytic anemia is seen in HUS

questions.solution:
The hemolytic anemia in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) occurs as a result of mechanical RBC destruction caused by microthrombi. Hence, Coomb's test is negative.

There are two types of HUS, namely typical and atypical.

Typical HUS Atypical HUS
  • 5-10 days after diarrheal illness
  • E.coli O157:H7 or Shigella dysenteriae type I
  • Mutation in genes encoding complement regulatory protein
  • Shiga-like toxins produced cause endothelial damage.
  • This leads to platelet activation and thrombi.
  • Uncontrolled activation of the complement system
  • No specific treatment
  • Supportive management of renal failure
  • Plasma exchange to replace the deficient proteins
  • Eculizumab, a C5 inhibitor

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset headache and photophobia. On examination, she is disoriented and febrile. The investigations and peripheral smear are given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this disease?

Hemoglobin - 11.2 g/dl

Platelet count - 32,000/uL

Serum creatinine - 3.9 mg/dl

Blood urea nitrogen - 38 mg/dl

choices.text: It is caused by ADAMTS13 deficiency
20% patients  will have falsely positive  RA factor
Arrhythmias are a frequent cause of death
Mainstay of treatment is blood transfusion

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) in a woman are suggestive of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Blood transfusion is not preferred in TTP as it can aggravate the condition.

TTP is a type of thrombotic microangiopathy that occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the ADAMTS13 metalloprotease, which is responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor multimers. In the absence of this protein, vWF multimers aggregate and form thrombi. It presents with a classical pentad of clinical features:

  1. Fever
  2. Thrombocytopenia
  3. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  4. Renal failure
  5. Neurological manifestations

It is treated with plasmapheresis and rituximab.

questions.text: What is the most​ common cause of clinically significant renal artery stenosis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of clinically significant renal artery stenosis is atherosclerosis.

Renal artery stenosis is a relatively common finding in older patients with chronic essential hypertension. However, it is considered clinically significant only when renovascular hypertension develops. It occurs in the case of:

  • > 70% stenosis in both renal arteries
  • > 50% stenosis with post stenotic dilatation

The causes of renal artery stenosis are:

  • Atherosclerosis (most common) - common in older patients with cardiovascular risk factors
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia – more common in young, white females and is usually bilateral
  • Less common causes include:
    • Thromboemboli
    • External compression by tumors
    • Systemic vasculitis
    • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
    • Transplant renal artery stenosis
    • Infrarenal aortic aneurysms and dissections

The investigation of choice for renal artery stenosis is renal angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about fibromuscular dysplasia?

choices.text: String of beads appearance on angiography
Most commonly affected peripheral artery is subclavian artery

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and the string of beads appearance on CT angiography is characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia. The most common peripheral (limb) arteries affected are the iliac arteries.

Fibromuscular dysplasia is a segmental, non-atheromatous, dysplastic type of angiopathy that predominantly affects females. The most common subtype is medial fibroplasia. It is one of the major causes of renovascular hypertension. The most common sites of involvement in decreasing order of frequency are as follows:

  1. Renal arteries
  2. Carotid arteries
  3. Peripheral (limb) arteries - most commonly iliac arteries

On angiography, a string of beads appearance is seen as shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely in patients with atheroembolic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Atheroembolic kidney disease is associated with decreased complement levels.

Atheroembolic kidney disease is more frequent in males with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and ischemic heart disease.  Most clinical atheroembolic events follow angiographic procedures, often of the coronary vessels.

It is associated with aortic aneurysms and renal artery stenosis. Systemic embolic manifestations such as fever, abdominal pain, and weight loss are also present, although cutaneous manifestations are more common like livedo reticularis and localized toe gangrene.

The lab findings include:

  • Rising serum creatinine
  • Transient eosinophilia
  • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • Hypocomplementemia

Definitive diagnosis depends on kidney biopsy which demonstrates microvessel occlusion with cholesterol crystals that leave a cleft in the vessel as shown below.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is being evaluated for uncontrolled hypertension despite being on 3 antihypertensive drugs. He has a history of myocardial infarction which was managed with percutaneous intervention last month. On examination, an abdominal bruit is noted. Lab values indicate elevated serum urea and creatinine. Which of the following investigations is the gold standard test to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal artery stenosis. Renal intra-arterial angiography is the gold standard for diagnosis.In a patient with hypertension and increased creatinine, an ultrasound of the abdomen must be performed first to visualize the renal size and morphology to look for a unilateral shrunken kidney and thereby renal artery stenosis. 

Option A: MR angiography is less preferred as gadolinium contrast can lead to nephrogenic fibrosis, particularly in patients with reduced kidney function.

Option C: CT scan with image reconstruction provides an excellent image but also carries a risk of contrast nephropathy.

Option D: Renal arterial doppler ultrasound measures renal artery velocities and can predict hemodynamically important lesions. However, it is not the gold standard test. Duplex ultrasonography is used as a screening investigation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs must be avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors must be avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis (RAS).

In renal artery stenosis, blood flow to the kidney is reduced, thereby reducing blood flow to the afferent arterioles. Hence, constriction of efferent arterioles is needed to maintain hydrostatic pressure within the glomerulus in order to maintain GFR.

ACEIs and ARBs inhibit efferent renal arteriolar vasoconstriction. In bilateral RAS, this causes a decline in the GFR within a few days of starting the drug.

Note: Bilateral renal artery stenosis has been classically considered as an absolute contraindication to the use of ACE inhibitors. However, new studies show that they may be used in some cases with careful monitoring.
